importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the incident, when the Emirates cargo plane skidded off the runway, is significant as it marks a recent and tragic aviation event at Hong Kong International Airport, contributing to public concern over airport safety and emergency response protocols.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The specific landing time of the Emirates flight EK9788 is crucial as it helps establish the sequence of events and contextualize the incident within operational hours, highlighting potential issues with landing procedures or runway guidance.

keyTakeAways: An Emirates cargo plane (flight EK9788) skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and crashed into the sea, killing two ground staff.
The plane was operating under a wet lease from Turkish carrier Act Airlines, meaning it was equipped and crewed by Turkish operators but operated under Emirates brand.
The two fatalities were a 30-year-old and a 41-year-old ground staff member with seven and 12 years of experience, respectively.
The aircraft, a Boeing 747-481, sustained damage during landing; all four crew members survived and were rescued within two minutes by fire services.
The plane did not send a distress signal, turned away from the runway, and crashed through fencing into a patrol vehicle, which then went into the sea.
The airport officials confirm that the patrol vehicle was outside the runway fencing and not on the runway.
The flight data recorder (FDR) and cockpit voice recorder (CVR) are still being recovered from the sea by the Hong Kong Air Accident Investigation Authority (AAIA).
This marks the second deadly incident at Hong Kong International Airport since its move to Chek Lap Kok in 1998, with the previous being a 1999 China Airlines crash during a typhoon.
At least 11 cargo flights were cancelled due to the incident, and the affected runway remains closed, though operations continue on the other two runways.
A criminal investigation is being considered, indicating unresolved concerns about possible negligence or error in flight or ground operations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: An Emirates cargo flight (EK9788) arriving from Dubai skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport during landing at around 03:50 local time, crashing through fencing and colliding with an airport patrol vehicle, killing two ground staff members aged 30 and 41. The plane, a Boeing 747-481 wet-leased from Turkish carrier Act Airlines, sustained significant damage but all four crew members survived due to rapid emergency response and deployment of evacuation slides. Airport officials state that the patrol vehicle was safely outside the runway and that the plane did not send a distress signal. The incident marks the second fatal aviation event at Hong Kong’s airport since 1998, with the previous being a 1999 China Airlines crash. The Hong Kong Air Accident Investigation Authority is actively searching for the flight data and cockpit voice recorders. The affected runway remains closed, and at least 11 cargo flights have been cancelled. A criminal investigation is being considered, and public concerns remain about landing procedures and safety protocols.
title: Two dead after Emirates cargo plane skids off Hong Kong runway into sea
